If any of your other soldiers are within 10 feet of the target of the attack, they can strike as part of the attack, and if the attack hits, the creature takes an additional d4 force damage for each soldier beyond the first.
When you gain the Extra Attack feature, you can forgo each attack you make as part of the Attack action to command your soldiers to strike.

subclassFeature.name: Rise to War
entries: At 7th level, you're able to quickly prepare for battle. When you summon a soldier during the first round of combat, you can summon a second soldier as part of the same bonus action. Once you do so, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

Additionally, you have advanced knowledge of battles in ages past. Whenever you make a History check relating to battles, warfare, or a military keep or fortification, you can treat a roll of 7 or lower on the d20 as an 8.

subclassFeature.name: Conqueror's Reach
entries: At 10th level, your dominion over battle allows you to greater control of your army. You can command your soldiers while you're within 60 feet of them. Additionally, the damage dice of your Conqueror's Strike increases to a d10. At 18th level, it increases to a d12.

subclassFeature.name: Rank and File
entries: At 15th level, hostile creatures treat any space within 10 feet of your soldiers as difficult terrain.

subclassFeature.name: Unyielding Advance
entries: Starting at 18th level, your soldiers strike with unnatural accuracy. Attack rolls you make using your soldiers can't suffer disadvantage.

subclassFeature.name: Gunslinger
entries: Should this path of powder, fire, and metal call to you, keep your wits about you, hold on to your convictions as a fighter, and let skill meet luck to guide your bullets to strike true.

subclassFeature.name: Firearm Proficiency
entries: Starting when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@table Firearms|Hergard}, allowing you to add your proficiency bonus to attacks made with firearms.

subclassFeature.name: Gunsmith
entries: Upon choosing this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with Tinker's Tools. You may use them to craft ammunition at half the cost, repair damaged firearms, or even draft and create new ones (DM's discretion). Some extremely experimental and intricate firearms are only available through crafting.

subclassFeature.name: Adept Marksman
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to perform powerful trick shots to disable or damage your opponents using your firearms.

entries.name: Trick Shots.
entries: You learn two trick shots of your choice, which are detailed under {@filter Trick Shots |optionalfeatures|feature type=Trick Shots} below. Many trick shots enhance an attack in some way. Each use of a trick shot must be declared before the attack roll is made. You can use only one trick shot per attack and you cannot use a trick shot for the same attack as a maneuver.
You learn an additional trick shot of your choice at 7th, 10th, 15th, and 18th level. Each time you learn a new trick shot, you can also replace one trick shot you know with a different one.

entries.name: Grit.
entries: You gain a number of grit points equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You regain 1 expended grit point each time you roll a 20 on the d20 roll for an attack with a firearm, or deal a killing blow with a firearm to a creature of significant threat (DM's discretion). You regain all expended grit points after a short or long rest.

entries.name: Saving Throws.
entries: Some of your trick shots require your targets to make a saving throw to resist the trick shot's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

subclassFeature.name: Quickdraw
entries: When you reach 7th level, you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative. You can also stow a firearm, then draw another firearm as a single object interaction on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Rapid Repair
entries: Upon reaching 10th level, you learn how to quickly attempt to fix a jammed gun. You can spend a grit point to attempt to repair a misfired (but not broken) firearm as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Lightning Reload
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can reload any firearm as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious Intent
entries: At 18th level, your firearm attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19-20, and you regain a grit point on a roll of 19 or 20 on a d20 attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Hemorrhaging Critical
entries: Upon reaching 18th level, whenever you score a critical hit on an attack with a firearm, the target additionally suffers half of the damage from the attack at the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Purple Dragon Knight
entries: Purple Dragon knights are warriors who pledged to protect the crown, as they take the fight against evil beyond their kingdom's borders. They are tasked with wandering the land as knights errant, relying on their judgment, bravery, and fidelity to the code of chivalry to guide them in defeating evildoers.

A Purple Dragon knight inspires greatness in others by committing brave deeds in battle. The mere presence of a knight in a hamlet is enough to cause some orcs and bandits to seek easier prey. A lone knight is a skilled warrior, but a knight leading a band of allies can transform even the most poorly equipped militia into a ferocious war band as the knight's actions can awaken reserves of courage and conviction in allies that they never suspected they had.

subclassFeature.name: Knight Training
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Animal Handling, Insight, Intimidation or Performance. Alternatively, you learn one language of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Banner
entries: At 3rd level, you can craft a banner, or use an existing one, to represent your order. It can be held in one hand and weighs 6 pounds. Furling or unfurling the banner requires an action. While your banner is unfurled and you are not incapacitated, you and all allies within 10 feet of you gain a +1 bonus on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws, provided they can see your banner.
If your banner is lost or destroyed, you can make a new one using 50 gp in raw materials over the course of an hour or a short rest.
The banner's unfurled bonus increases by 1 and its range increases by 5 feet at 7th, 15th and 18th level.

subclassFeature.name: Rallying Cry
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn how to inspire your allies to fight on past their injuries. When you use your Second Wind feature, you can choose a number of non-hostile creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) within 30 feet of you that can see or hear you. Each one regains hit points equal to your fighter level, provided that the creature can see or hear you.
If your banner is unfurled while using this ability and you aren't incapacitated, each one of those allies within the banner's range gains additional temporary hit points equal to your fighter level.

subclassFeature.name: Royal Envoy
entries: Starting at 7th level, your discipline and knightly character is a shining example of the crown. A Purple Dragon knight serves as an envoy of the crown. Knights of high standing are expected to conduct themselves with grace. You gain proficiency in the Persuasion skill and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses it.
Additionally, you learn two languages of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Inspiring Surge
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you use your Action Surge feature, you can choose three creatures within 60 feet of you to inspire with martial prowess. Chosen creatures can use their reaction to make one melee or ranged weapon attack, provided that they can see or hear you.
At 18th level, you can choose six allies within 60 feet of you, rather than three.

subclassFeature.name: Lead the Charge
entries: Beginning at 10th level, if your banner is unfurled, you and all allies within the banner's range gain a bonus to initiative rolls equal to your banner's unfurled bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Bulwark
entries: At 15th level, you can extend the benefit of your Indomitable feature to allies in need. When an ally within 60 feet of you fails a saving throw, you can use your reaction to allow them to reroll that saving throw with a bonus equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).
At 18th level, if your banner is unfurled, you can expend one use of this ability to give creatures of your choice within its range advantage on their next saving throw.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Spellbreaker
entries: In the times when the knowledge of divine and arcane magic is ever-growing someone must step up to the task to protect the innocent from the forces of evil magic users. Through runic rituals these individuals learn to shield themselves and their allies from arcane and divine powers.
They call themselves: Spellbreakers.

subclassFeature.name: Spellbreaker's Runes
entries: Beginning when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, while you are not wearing any armor, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier. This comes from a process of creating runes that are applied to your body. Some Spellbreakers use magical inks to tattoo their skin, some scar their bodies to create these warding symbols upon themselves.

subclassFeature.name: Sigils of Disruption
entries: Also at 3rd level, you are able to harness the power of the runes on your body and use their innate power to perform a number of anti-magic abilities. You gain the following maneuver options. They don't count against your number of maneuvers known.

entries.name: Purge.
entries: As an action, you can expend one superiority die and attempt to dispel an ongoing magical effect within 30 feet of you. Make an Intelligence check against a DC of 10 + the level of the spell that you are trying to dispel. On a success, the spell is dispelled. If the spell has a permanent duration, the spell's effects are instead suppressed for 1 minute.

entries.name: Negate.
entries: When you see an enemy within 30 feet of you casting a spell, you can expend one superiority die and use your reaction to attempt to prevent them from casting. Make an Intelligence check against a DC of 10 + the spell's level. On a success, the spell fails to materialize, but the caster retains their spell slot.

entries.name: Sabotage.
entries: As a reaction, you may expend one superiority die to cast shield on yourself without somatic components.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Lore
entries: Starting at 7th level, your knowledge of magical items allows you to cast identify and detect magic as rituals. If you cast one of the listed spells with this feature, they do not require the material components.

subclassFeature.name: Warding Sigil
entries: Beginning at 10th level, your understanding of the arcane allows you to move enchantments from an item to your Spellbreaker's Runes. You can spend one hour a day to conduct a sacred ritual in which you move the enchantment from a set of magical armor to your skin. This hour can be part of a short or long rest. The number of days this task requires is determined by the rarity of the item, detailed in the Ritual Period table below. If you attempt to move the enchantment of a sentient item or an artifact, you immediately gain three levels of exhaustion from the strain on your body and mind and the ritual fails.
After you move the enchantment to your body, the original set of armor is rendered non-magical but still functional.
You may only have one enchantment gained from this feature on you at a time. If you attempt to move another enchantment to your Spellbreaker's Runes, the previous enchantment fades.

subclassFeature.name: Unending Watch
entries: Starting at 15th level, if you roll initiative and have no Runes of Disruption left, you regain 1 use of the feature.
Additionally, you gain a bonus to your initiative rolls equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: High-Warden
entries: From 18th level, you gain the ability to focus your runes in an unyieldingly honed way, harnessing the powers of abjuration to negate harmful magic towards you and your allies. As an action you can summon a translucent barrier of anti-magic, made of warding glyphs and sigils.

The barrier is a 15-feet-wide 10-feet-high wall that is projected 5 feet in front of you and lasts for a number of rounds equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). You concentrate on this feature as if it was a spell. Creatures may pass through the barrier without harm, but any magical piece of ammunition shot through is rendered non-magical. Any spell of 4th level or lower has no effect on a creature or object on the other side of the barrier, but can still target them.
As a bonus action on subsequent turns you may move the barrier to a space within 15 feet of its previous location.
You regain the use of this feature after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Burning
entries: Those whose rage causes fire typically are defined by a tragic experience with the element. Their homestead may have been burned, killing their family. Possibly they were badly burned as a child during a ritual. Or maybe they accidentally killed their own friend by pushing them into a firepit. No matter the source, fire is deeply ingrained in their soul. When they are overtaken by emotion and anger, this fire comes loose. The primordial element feeds off their rage like a fuel, channeling their anger in a blaze around them.

A barbarian whose rage brings forth flames is distinct from others who do the same. Perhaps the fire that caused their rage was so hot, it glowed blue and white. The barbarian's rage may mirror this, releasing blue fire in their rage. Or if the barbarian nearly suffocated in the fire's smoke, their own fire will release similar, thick, dark smoke.

subclassFeature.name: Fiery Rage
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you erupt into flames when you start your rage. You gain resistance to cold damage and fire damage, and at the end of each of your turns, each creature within 5 feet takes fire damage equal to your Rage bonus damage, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.

subclassFeature.name: Molten Armor
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you ignite yourself using Fiery Rage, a sheet of basalt covers your body. You gain temporary hit points equal to your barbarian level and you have advantage on Constitution saving throws while you are raging.

subclassFeature.name: Ashen Body
entries: Starting at 10th level, whenever you take damage from a melee attack, you may use your reaction to turn the skin at the point of impact into ash. If you do, you have resistance to all damage from that attack.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Erupt
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your action to blow a gout of fire at your enemies from your mouth. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier). A creature takes 6d10 fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
Additionally, while you are ignited using Fiery Rage, you are immune to fire damage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Jötunnkyn
entries: Some rare individuals have been born with a great aptitude to develop astonishing physical traits - standing a head taller in almost any crowd, their forearms the size of tree stumps or their strength unparalleled among their race.

Legend says that the rarest of them actually have the blood of giants coursing through their veins. These individuals are often called Jötunnkyn. Whether through a common lineage, giant blooded ancestors or some ancient and forgotten form of magic, you are a descendant of the Jötnar and their traits are visible in your very physique.

While some may take these gifts for granted, barbarians who follow this path seek to embrace their inner power and often become great heroes that inspire folk tales and legends larger than life itself.

entries.subclassFeature: Restriction - Size matters|Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Jötunnkyn|Hergard|3

subclassFeature.name: Restriction - Size matters
entries: The blood of giants flows only through those innately strong enough to caress its full potential. This path can only be taken by characters whose race is of a medium size or larger.

subclassFeature.name: Jotunous Crimson
entries: You never quite fit in, both metaphorically and literally. As you start embracing your innate power these traits become even more pronounced.

Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, your hit point maximum increases by 3, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level in this class. You also gain proficiency with improvised weapons and can speak, read, and write Giant.
Additionally, you count as one size larger when determining whom you can grapple or shove as well as for determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

subclassFeature.name: Colossal Might
entries: Your natural talents grow as does the confidence with which you utilize them.

Beginning at 3rd level, whenever you enter a rage you are immune to the frightened condition for the duration and if you are wielding a versatile weapon in one hand, you can use its two handed damage die.
Furthermore, your normal and long range for all weapons with the thrown property are doubled.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Grip
entries: The mere strength of your grip is enough to shatter bones and wield weapons that are too heavy for ordinary men.
At 6th level, you gain proficiency in the Athletics skill if you don't already have it. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this proficiency.
Additionally, while you are raging, you can use two-weapon fighting even when the one-handed melee weapons you are wielding aren't light.

subclassFeature.name: Seize the Momentum
entries: You see every combat as game rather then an obstacle. The challenges set in front of you only give you a sense of vigor and excitement, each exchanged blow making the battle even sweeter.

Starting at 10th level, whenever you score a critical hit, you may choose to push the target 10 feet in a straight line away from you or knock it prone. Whenever you are struck by a critical hit, your next weapon attack deals additional damage equal to half your barbarian level.
Additionally, the area within 5 feet of you is considered difficult terrain at all times to creatures of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Fury of the Giantkin
entries: You have fully embraced the blood of Jotun and fellow giants may even begrudgingly accept you as their kin.

Starting from 14th level, whenever you enter a rage, you may choose to grow in size as if affected by the enlarge option of the enlarge/reduce spell. While enlarged in this way, you deal double damage to objects and structures.
This effect is not considered as casting a spell, nor does it require concentration to maintain and it lasts until your rage ends or you decide to end it at will.
Additionally, if you successfully grapple a creature that is at least one size category smaller than you while enlarged in this way, it is restrained.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Mistwalker
entries: The air grows chill as darkness falls across the water, a cold mist rising from the depths of a dark lake. Suddenly the chill is interrupted by the sound of steal, and moments later the deadly dance has come to an end; the watch cut down before they could so much as scream.
Not all barbarians allow their rage to control them, and so it is with the Mistwalkers. Silently they stalk their prey, letting fear consume them before striking from the mists.

subclassFeature.name: Mistweaver
entries: Starting at 3rd level, whenever you enter your rage you can choose to summon a 30-foot diameter sphere of mist originating from you. This mist wraps around corners but does not extend through solid objects, and its area is lightly obscured. While you are in this mist you can forgo any amount of your movement and cause your mist to move that distance instead. Your mist vanishes if you leave its area or your rage ends.
In addition, creatures of your choice in the mist can attempt to hide even if the mist is the only thing obscuring them from the creature they are attempting to hide from.

subclassFeature.name: Dewstride
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn to move through your mist as if you were one. When you begin your rage and as a bonus action on subsequent turns while you rage you can teleport to any location you can see within your mist. You can use this bonus action only if you haven't moved during that turn, and after you use the bonus action, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn. After teleporting in this way, if you hit a creature with your next attack on the same turn, that creature becomes frightened of you until the end of your next turn. Once you frighten a creature in this way you can't do so again until you rage again.

subclassFeature.name: Rain's Boon
entries: Starting at 6th level, your link to the mists grants you special gifts. You learn the create or destroy water, pass without trace, and water walk spells and can cast each of them once without expending a spell slot or material components.
You regain the ability to do so when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Lurking Fury
entries: Starting at 10th level, your connection to the mists grow, granting you one of the following benefits of your choice:

items: You can take the Hide action as a bonus action on your turn. This can be the same bonus action you take to enter your rage.
Creatures of your choice treat your mists area as difficult terrain.
You score a critical hit against creatures frightened by you on a roll of 18-20.

entries: Whenever you finish a long rest you can change which effect you benefit from.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Fog
entries: Starting at 14th level, as an action on your turn while you are raging, you may force a number of creatures of your choice within your mist equal to your proficiency bonus to succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of the mist until your rage ends. A creature frightened in this way may repeat their saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending it on a success. Once you do so you can’t do so again until you rage again. Using your action in this way counts as attacking a hostile creature in terms of maintaining your rage.
You can use this ability only once per rage.
Additionally, while you are in your mist you can see anything within its area as if you had blindsight, and can see into the ethereal plane within the same area.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Red Oak
entries: The Red Oak are trees of mysterious origin. They seem to have been created at the time of the Split, but their true purpose is unknown. The Cobalt Soul claims they are representations of Élan's wrath towards her children, but records or evidence have not been unearthed proving such an idea. However one thing is known: A select few tribes – whose bloodline survived the Old War – guard the secret recipe to the Red Oak Elixir, a potion of immense power, unknown even to the Cobalt Soul.

entries.subclassFeature: Red Oak Elixir|Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Red Oak|Hergard|3

subclassFeature.name: Red Oak Elixir
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you have been gifted with the ancient secret of the Red Oak Elixir, a potion designed to bring you into a state of heightened ferocity and increased strength. Your rage gains the following effects:

items: On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action by drinking a Red Oak Elixir. Consuming a Red Oak Elixir always activates your rage. If you do not have an elixir or any free hands (e.g. you are restrained), you cannot enter a rage.
While raging, you have advantage on Constitution checks and saving throws.
While raging, you are immune to poison damage and the poisoned condition.
While raging, your skin gains a rough, bark-like appearance, and your AC can't be less than 16, regardless of what kind of armor you are wearing.

entries: You can make a number of Red Oak Elixirs per long rest equal to your number of Rages as shown in the Rages column of the Barbarian table. A Red Oak Elixir loses its potency after 24 hours and is no longer effective. A Red Oak Elixir has no effect on creatures other than you.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Resilience
entries: At 6th level, you are able to alter your Red Oak Elixir to make you more durable. When you consume your Red Oak Elixir, you gain resistance to one of the following damage types of your choice for the duration of your rage: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder.
You gain resistance to an additional damage type of your choice from the list at 10th and again at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Arboreal Bond
entries: At 10th level, moving through nonmagical difficult terrain costs you no extra movement. You can also pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them, without taking damage from their thorns, spines, or any similar hazards. You have advantage on saving throws against plants that are magically created or manipulated to impede movement, such as those created by the entangle spell.

Additionally, by expanding one Red Oak Elixir, you can imbue a single tree within 30 feet of you with limited sentience and animation, giving it the ability to communicate with you and follow your simple commands for a limited time.

For the duration you can communicate with the tree in your known languages and can question it about events within the past day, gaining information about creatures that have passed, weather, and other circumstances.

The tree might be able to perform other tasks on your behalf, at the GM's discretion. This feature doesn't enable a tree to uproot itself and move about, but it can freely move its branches, roots, and leaves.
This effect lasts for a number of minutes equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Root and Branch
entries: At 14th level, while raging, you are able to take on some of the aspects of the trees of the forest. Your rage gains the following additional effects:

items: Magic can't put you to sleep..
Whenever you suffer a critical hit, you can turn that hit into a normal hit.
You are vulnerable to fire damage.

entries.name: Branch Slam.
entries: As a bonus action, your arm elongates and becomes branch-like, allowing you to make a melee attack against a single opponent within 15 feet of you that deals 3d6 bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Entangling Vines.
entries: As a bonus action, vines erupt from your body and entangle a single target within 30 feet. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained by the entangling vines until your rage ends or you choose to release them. A creature restrained by the vines can use its action to make a Strength check against DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier. On a success, it frees itself.
You may only have a single target restrained by entangling vines at any one time.

entries.name: Earthen Roots.
entries: As a reaction, you send roots deep into the earth. For the duration of your rage, you cannot be moved against your will or knocked prone by non-magical means. For any magical attempts to move you (such as from levitate or telekinesis), you have advantage on the save or ability check to resist the effect.

entries.name: Briar Thorns.
entries: As a reaction, your body sprouts hard spikes and thorns. Any creature grappling you, grappled by you, or in contact with your body suffers 2d4 piercing damage at the start of each of its turns.

entries.name: Sap Blood.
entries: Any time you take a wound, as a reaction, you can create a number of drops of hardened sap equal to your proficiency bonus. These sap drops appear in your hand.
A creature can use a bonus action to eat one drop. Eating a drop restores 1d4 hit points. The sap loses its potency if it not consumed during your rage.

entries.name: Tree Walker.
entries: As a bonus action, you gain the ability to use trees as pathways of nature. You cast tree stride without expending material components. This effect doesn't require concentration and lasts for the duration of your rage.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Rune Warrior
entries: The rage state drives reason from the mind, preventing most barbarians from wielding magic. Barbarians of this path reject this limitation, using natural, magic-imbued tattoos to always have their spells at the ready, so their instincts can manage the execution.

entries.subclassFeature: Runic Tattooer|Barbarian|PHB|Path of the Rune Warrior|Hergard|3

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you augment your brute strength with the ability to cast spells.

entries.name: Cantrip Tattoos.
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list, stored on your body as minor tattoos. You learn one additional druid cantrip at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Tattoos.
entries: You have numerous glyphs, symbols and sigils on your body that let you cast magic when you unseal their power. Each one of your tattoos hold a limited amount of natural magic, after which it becomes inept until you rest. The Rune Warrior Spellcasting table shows how many spell tattoos you have to cast your spells of 1st-level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend one spell charge of the spell tattoo's level, much like a wizard might expend a spell slot. However each tattoo represents one single spell, allowing you to tattoo a spell at a higher level onto yourself. You regain all expended spell tattoo charges when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know of the first level spell absorb elements, you may tattoo it on yourself as a second level spell thus you must use a second level spell charge every time you cast it.

entries.name: Spell Tattoos of 1st-Level and Higher.
entries: You have three first level druid spells of your choice tattooed on your body.

The Spell Tattoos column of the table shows when you gain additional druid spells of 1st-level or higher. Each of these spells must be tattooed on your body, stored permanently at the level you choose to cast it at, and must be of a level for which you have spell charges.
For instance when you reach 7th level in this class you may learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level and have it tattooed onto yourself as a 2nd-level spell.

entries.name: Sacred Ritual.
entries: Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can perform a series of rituals to replace one of the druid spells you know with another spell of your choice from the druid spell list. The new spell must be of a level which you have spell charges for. The rituals must take a cumulative 24 hours and cause you to lose access to the spell you are replacing for the duration.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability.
entries: Constitution is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells , since you channel your natural magic through the unleashed power of your ritual tattoos. You use your Constitution whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Constitution modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Runic Tattooer
entries: Also at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with a special set of tools, the Tattooer's tools. This is a special set of tools containing a prepared and sharpened reed, natural permanent ink and a special toxin that makes the skin insensitive. These tools are used to create tattoos through a secret ritual perfected over centuries.

Additionally, your mind is accustomed to casting while in a state of rage. When you rage, you may cast non-concentration spells as normal if you have tattooed the specific spell on yourself. The tattoos count as material components for any spell that requires, but does not consume them and you continue to rage when you cast a spell since your last turn. When you use your Reckless Attack feature, you can choose for it to take effect on your melee spell attack rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Dynamo
entries: Beginning at 6th level, when you are hit by a spell, you absorb a small amount of magical power, reinvigorating your tattoos. Whenever you suffer damage from a spell, you may use your reaction to absorb some of its magical power and regain an expended spell charge of equal level to the spell. If you are hit by a spell of 6th-level or higher, you regain a 5th-level spell charge.
You regain the use of this ability after you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Furious Caster
entries: At 10th level, when you cast a spell while raging, you may add your Strength modifier to its attack and damage rolls.

Additionally, you learn 3 spells of 3rd level or lower, with the Ritual tag from any spell list. You may cast these spells as rituals, without providing material components. If you are raging while casting these spells as rituals, the time it takes to cast them is halved. You may cast these spells a combined number of times equal to your Constitution modifier and can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Rage Insignia
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can transfer the energy from your tattoos onto another creature or object temporarily marking it with a shimmering copy of your tattoo. As a bonus action, you may cast one of your spells that doesn't have the range of self and touch a creature or object.

If it is a creature, it must make a Constitution saving throw; a creature can choose to fail this saving throw if it wishes. On a success, your spell fades and the spell charge is lost. On a failed save, they become marked by your spell. If the spell requires you to choose from multiple effects, you make your choice when creating the mark. If the spell's range is touch and your mark is on an object, it gains a range of 5 feet. The mark lasts for 1 hour.

Once a creature or object is marked, you may spend an action to activate the spell as though it was cast from the object or creature's location. If the spell requires a target, the target becomes the nearest creature within the spell's range. If the spell requires multiple targets, they are selected in order of how far they are from the glyph.
You may have a total number of glyphs cast at a time equal to your Constitution modifier, but you can only activate one at a time. You regain all uses of this feature when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Death Domain
entries: The Death domain is concerned with the forces of death, as well as the negative energy that gives rise to undead creatures. Gods of the Death domain embody murder like Guerro, pain like Harkonar, disease or poison like Hegna, and the underworld like Hel. The suffering of mortal life is temporary, undeath is forever.

subclassFeature.name: Death Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Death Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons and heavy armor.

subclassFeature.name: Fear the Inevitable
entries: At 1st level, you can use your action to instill fear in a creature. Choose a creature within 30 feet that you can see, the creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your cleric spell save DC. On a failed save, the target is frightened of you and its speed is halved until the end of your next turn.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once) and regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Touch of Death
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to destroy another creature's life force by touch.
When you hit a creature with a melee attack, you can use Channel Divinity to deal extra necrotic damage to the target. The damage equals 5 + twice your cleric level.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Ward
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can store life energy within yourself to later protect you. In its stored form, this energy is called a Soul charge.

You can store a maximum number of soul charges equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of one). Whenever you finish a long rest, your number of soul charges resets to one. Whenever you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points, you gain one soul charge. If you end a short rest with no soul charges, you gain one soul charge.
Once per round when you make a saving throw, you can expend a soul charge to add 1d6 to the result.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 necrotic damage. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Death
entries: Starting at 17th level, you can invoke an avatar of death to claim the soul of a creature. As an action, you can mark a creature within 60 feet of you for death.

A shadowy reaper appears before the marked creature, sharing its space and hovering a foot above them. The reaper shares your statistics, but has hit points equal to three times your cleric level and AC equal to 10 + your Wisdom modifier, and it cannot take actions. It lasts for one minute, or until either it or its mark is slain.

At the start of each of the marked creatures turns, the reaper swings its scythe downwards. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or take necrotic damage equal to twice your cleric level.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Fate Domain
entries: Diviners and wizards often attempt to peer at the threads that bind the lives of mortals, but gods are the ones who weave those threads with every new birth and death. Parash, Mergoda, Lugor, Hegna, Fortuna, Mallorie, Singulor, Chrona and other deities of life, death, glory, time, judgement, luck, and prophecy call upon their clerics to act as oracles and seers of fate and future - and to intervene when the time is right. Those who follow benevolent gods often guide heroes to their destinies, while evil oracles may lead them astray or attempt to meddle with the future to bring prophecies of ruin, destruction and chaos to fruition.

subclassFeature.name: Fate Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Fate Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Aid the Misguided
entries: When you choose this domain at first level, you gain the guidance and resistance cantrips. You may choose to cast them as a bonus action, a combined number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses of this feature after you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Eye of the Oracle
entries: Also at 1st level, your god bestows a mark upon you that signifies your attunement to the threads of fate, such as a third eye, runic tattoo, or halo of mist, which you can conceal at will. While your mark is revealed, you can use your action to gaze into the future of another humanoid within 60 feet of you. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or you gain truesight against them until the end of your next turn and their surface thoughts and intentions become known to you. If a creature succeeds on their save, they are immune to the effects of this feature for the next 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Severed Threads
entries: At 2nd level, your god grants you the ability to manipulate fate directly. Whenever you deal damage to a creature, you can use a bonus action and your Channel Divinity feature to attempt to cut its ties to mortality. The target must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failure, their fate is disrupted, gaining disadvantage on the next three attack rolls or saving throws they make.

subclassFeature.name: Discarded Tatters
entries: At 6th level, you collect the scattered threads of fate for a new tapestry of your own devising. Whenever you are hit by a weapon attack, you can use your reaction to weave an ethereal cloak around yourself made from the destiny of your attacker. The attacker must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failure they take force damage equal to the amount of damage they inflict on you, or half as much on a success.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to half your Wisdom modifier rounded up. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Prophetic Glimpse
entries: At 17th level, your god grants you the ability to see brief yet perfectly accurate visions of the future. Whenever you or a creature of your choice within 30 feet of you is hit by an attack, you may use your reaction to change the outcome. Make a Spell Attack roll with advantage, contested by the attack roll made against the target. If you roll equal to or higher than the attack roll, it misses completely.
You may use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Love Domain
entries: Clerics of the Love Domain follow the clergy of gods of love, passion and desire. Make no mistake, gods like Helegor, Aeris and even Mergoda don't limit their domains to romantic love, they enjoy brotherly love between siblings, the love between a child and their parents and even love between a group of friends. Their clerics seek to spread love, happiness and peace between all things. They perform marriages, assist in childbirth, and always encourage kindness. But most of all, they provide a sense of strength and camaraderie in any group that they happen to find themselves a part of.

subclassFeature.name: Love Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Love Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

entries.caption: Love Domain Spells
rows: {@spell aura of vitality|PHB}, {@spell beacon of hope|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: When you choose this domain at first level, you gain the friends cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Brotherly Love
entries: Also at 1st level, your jovial disposition leaves those you interact with cheerful and happy. When you cast friends or charm person on a creature, you may mask the usage of magic. After the spell ends, the target doesn't know you used magic on them, and they feel a slight sense of love and camaraderie towards you instead of hostility. The creature's feelings end if it or any of its companions are attacked by you or your companions, or the next time is sees you after 1 minute has elapsed. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Heart's Embrace
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to buoy up your allies with your boundless adoration, turning away blows and strengthening their resolve.

As an action, you may choose a number of allies you can see within 30 feet of you equal to your Wisdom modifier. They get a bonus to their AC and saving throws for the duration. This bonus equals half your Charisma modifier rounded up. They also gain temporary HP equal to your Charisma modifier at the start of each of their turns. This effect lasts for one minute, or until they end their turn 30 feet or more away from you.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Overwhelming Infatuation
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your Channel Divinity to cause a creature to become enamored with another, pursuing the subject of its affection and hindering its movement.

As an action, you may cause a creature within 60 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, they are charmed and will use their action to run towards and show affection to another creature of your choosing within 30 feet of the target. The affected creature will not do anything overtly suicidal such as diving off a cliff or running into lava to get to the object of their desire. At the start of each of the object of desire's turns, if the target is within 5 feet of them, they must make a contested grapple check or be restrained until the start of their next turn, or until the target is no longer charmed.

The charmed effect lasts for 1 minute, but the target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Creatures that are immune to being charmed automatically succeed on the saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Charismatic Caster
entries: Starting at 17th level, when you cast an enchantment spell of 3rd level or lower, you may target an additional number of creatures equal to half your Charisma modifier rounded up.

subclassFeature.name: Secrecy Domain
entries: Not all knowledge should be found. There are some places, some eldritch whispers, that should be forgotten. These untellable truths about the world will be hunted. The clerics who devote themselves to Titok, goddess of secrets, safeguard this knowledge from falling into the hands of the unjust. Secrecy clerics are often unreadable and deceiving to their enemies, but greatly faithful and loyal to their allies.

subclassFeature.name: Secrecy Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Secrecy Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

entries.caption: Secrecy Domain Spells
rows: {@spell nystul's magic aura|PHB}, {@spell pass without trace|PHB}
{@spell leomund's secret chest|PHB}, {@spell mordenkainen's private sanctum|PHB}

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with martial weapons and the disguise kit.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Secrets
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the ability to communicate telepathically with any number of creatures that you can see within 30 feet. The creature must be able to speak at least one language, but you do not have to share a language with it. A creature may resist your mental communication by succeeding on a Wisdom saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Mask of the Unknown
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to cast the spell disguise self (no concentration required), through the connection of your god. You are able to cast this spell on other creatures by touching them as an action. A creature under the effects of the spell gains advantage on Charisma (Decep­tion) checks for the duration and can end the spell on itself at will.

subclassFeature.name: Mire the Mind of the Wicked
entries: Starting at 6th level, as a reaction, you can cause any creature that succeeds on a Wisdom or Intelligence saving throw to make the save again, forcing them to use the new result. You can do this a number of times equal to half your Wisdom modifier rounded up. You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to cut directly into the mind of your attackers. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra 1d8 psychic damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Sacred Knowledge
entries: Beginning at 17th level, your ability to gain and preserve secret lore is taken further in service of your deity. You are able to cast the spells alter self and invisibility (self only) a number of times equal to half your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once) at will. Additionally, you gain blindsight with a range of 30 feet and can see through magical darkness. Furthermore, you can double your proficiency bonus for Intelligence (Arcana), Intelligence (History) or Intelligence (Religion) checks in any matter that relates to obscure knowledge.

subclassFeature.name: Wind Domain
entries: The gods of the wind —including Agrodal, Ilxia, The Wanderess and Xild— value less attachment to places and people, and emphasize wanderlust and the following of one's own heart and life. “I go where the wind takes me” is an oft said phrase by adventurers, but none embody this as much as clerics of the wind domain. They seek to be truly free, casting off worries and downtrodden ties, embracing the beauty of following the wind.

entries.subclassFeature: Hand of the Wild Wind|Cleric|PHB|Wind Domain|Hergard|1
Protection of the Great Gale|Cleric|PHB|Wind Domain|Hergard|1

subclassFeature.name: Wind Domain Spells
entries: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Wind Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of the Wild Wind
entries: At 1st level, you gain the gust cantrip. The spell has a number of changes for you when you cast it:

items: It has a range of 60 feet.
You can choose Large or smaller creatures.
If a creature fails the Strength saving throw against being pushed, you can also magically deal 1d8 bludgeoning damage. This damage increases to 2d8 at 5th level, 3d8 at 11th, and 4d8 at 17th.

Instead of pushing a creature away when you deal damage, you can let the wild wind guide it. The creature moves 5 feet in a direction decided by the first d8 you roll for damage, instead of pushing it away from you. You can add your proficiency bonus to the result.

subclassFeature.name: Protection of the Great Gale
entries: Also at 1st level, the wind swirls around you in protection. While you are not wearing armor, your AC equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Wisdom modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Arm of the Bracing Breeze
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to bring down a torrent of wind, forcing foes back or forwards with a mighty barrage of air.

As an action, you present your holy symbol and choose a circle with a radius of 15 feet within 30 feet of you. Any fire not created by a magical effect is extinguished, be it burning a creature or an object. Additionally, each Huge or smaller hostile creature in the circle must make a Strength saving throw. A creature is pushed or pulled (your choice when you use this feature) 10 feet towards or away from the center of the circle and knocked prone on a failed saving throw, or 5 feet on a successful one.

subclassFeature.name: Grasp of the Carefree Cyclone
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can cast feather fall at will, without expending a spell slot. Additionally, you may cast the spell as a reaction to being thrown at a solid object horizontally.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Wrath of the Terrifying Tornado
entries: At 17th level, you can cast investiture of wind as a bonus action. When you have its benefits, your flying speed is increased to 90 feet, you can cast gust as a bonus action, and you have advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Astral
entries: Seers and fortune tellers have been reading the stars to predict the future for centuries, but the druids of the Astral Circle have a much deeper connection to the night sky. They study the stars to unlock their secrets, becoming capable of much more than mere fortune telling.

subclassFeature.name: Constellation Form
entries: At 1st level, you gain the gust cantrip. The spell has a number of changes for you when you cast it:

items: At 2nd level, when you choose this circle, whenever you use Wild Shape, you can instead take on a {@filter Constellation Form|optionalfeatures|feature type=Constellation Forms}. When you take on such a form, small stars form around your body showing the shape of the chosen constellation around you, an astral silhouette may appear over you, or the constellation appears as a mark on your body. While in a Constellation Form you gain its benefits, listed at the end of the circle's description, and can cast spells as you normally could outside of it.

Additionally, whenever you enter a Constellation Form, you gain 3 temporary hit points for each level you have in this class. The number of temporary hit points increases to 4 for each level at 10th level.
These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose all these temporary hit points, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Celestial Tongue
entries: Also at 2nd level, you learn to speak, read, and write Celestial.

subclassFeature.name: Star Reader
entries: At 6th level, you can read the stars for an omen of what's to come. You can cast augury, divination and commune as rituals. They can only be cast this way once per long rest each, and can only be used if you have clear view of the stars.
In addition, you cannot get lost by nonmagical means, as long as you have a clear view of the stars.

subclassFeature.name: Elysian Insight
entries: When you reach 10th level, the stars can shine upon an enemy revealing its weaknesses and secrets. As an action, a creature of your choice that you can see within a 60 feet radius must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, you learn the creature's name, creature type and one of the following attributes of your choosing:

items: damage resistances
damage vulnerabilities
damage immunities
condition immunities

entries: On a successful save the creature is immune to this feature for 24 hours and becomes aware of your influence. When you reach 14th level in this class, you learn one additional attribute when using this feature. Once you use this feature you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Stellar Ascendance
entries: At 14th level, you have gained a greater hold of mastery over your Constellation Forms. When you are in a Constellation Form, you can use a bonus action to activate an additional ability listed after the form's description. If these abilities have a duration, they will last their full duration even if you leave the form granting it, but if you use this feature again it cancels the current Ascendance power. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Silver Sands
entries: It is said that only the luckiest of druids come across the silver sands in the beaches and deserts across the world. They never appear in the same place twice and some believe they hold the intelligence to choose those they wish to bond with and bestow their power upon. None know this for sure, but what is certain is that those who utilize the sands weild great and reverent power that is to be both feared and admired.

entries.subclassFeature: Circle Spells|Druid|PHB|Circle of the Silver Sands|Hergard|2
Mystic Bond|Druid|PHB|Circle of the Silver Sands|Hergard|2
Sanctified Terrain|Druid|PHB|Circle of the Silver Sands|Hergard|2

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: The esoteric powers of the sands imbue you with the ability to cast certain spells.
At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to a number of circle spells, listed below in the silver sands table.

Once you gain access to a circle spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Silver Sands Spells

subclassFeature.name: Mystic Bond
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you always have a small stream of silver sand whirling around you that you can freely manipulate and control as an action. You must be able to see the sand to do so and it must be within 10 feet of you. If you ever lose your sand, it mysteriously appears back to you within 5 feet after 24 hours. Additionally, you may use the sands as a weapon. You are considered proficient with them and use your Wisdom as the attack and damage modifier. The sands have an attack range of 5 feet and deal 1d8 slashing damage.

subclassFeature.name: Sanctified Terrain
entries: Also at 2nd level, you may expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to scatter some of your sand around in a 30 foot radius centered on you that moves with you. This aura lasts for 1 minute and all hostile fey, fiends, celestials, undead, and elementals consider the area to be difficult terrain, take radiant damage equal to your Wisdom modifier at the start of their turn while within it, and are revealed to you if they are invisible or hidden in the area.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Sands
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, the bond you have with your sand has grown stronger. Your silver sand gains the following benefits:

items: When you attack with your sands they count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistances and immunities.
Your sand's attack range increases to 10 feet and the damage die becomes a d10.
You can now control your sands out to a maximum range of 20 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Granular Transport
entries: At 10th level, you can control your silver sands to rapidly whirl around you in order to provide you with elevated movement. As a bonus action, your movement speed increases by 30 feet and you gain a fly speed of 30 feet until the start of your next turn. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier and regain all uses after a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Hallowed Tempest
entries: Beginning at 14th level, as an action you create a magical sandstorm that stretches out around you by 30 feet and that follows you as you move for 1 minute. All friendly creatures within the storm gain temporary hit points equal to your Druid level at the start of each of their turns and have their movement speed increased by 10 feet for the duration of the storm. All hostile creatures that enter the storm or start their turn within it for the first time must make a Constitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC. On a failed save, while they're within the storm, they are blinded and gain vulnerability to slashing damage if they are not resistant or immune to it. If they are resistant, they lose their resistance and if they are immune, they are instead only resistant. Fey, fiends, celestials, undead, and elementals have disadvantage on this save.
Once you use this feature you may not do so again until your finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Spores
entries: Druids of the Circle of Spores find beauty in decay. They see within mold and other fungi the ability to transform lifeless material into abundant, albeit somewhat strange, life.

These druids believe that life and death are parts of a grand cycle, with one leading to the other and then back again. Death isn't the end of life, but instead a change of state that sees life shift into a new form.

Druids of this circle have a complex relationship with the undead. Unlike most other druids, they see nothing inherently wrong with undeath, which they consider to be a companion to life and death. But these druids believe that the natural cycle is healthiest when each segment of it is vibrant and changing. Undead that seek to replace all life with undeath, or that try to avoid passing to a final rest, violate the cycle and must be thwarted.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your symbiotic link to fungus and your ability to tap into the cycle of life and death grants you access to certain spells.
At 2nd level, you learn the chill touch cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Spores Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Halo of Spores
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you are surrounded by invisible necrotic spores that are harmless until you unleash them on a creature nearby. When a creature you can see moves into a space within 10 feet of you or starts its turn there, you can use your reaction to deal 1d4 necrotic damage to that creature unless it succeeds on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC, taking half damage on a successful save.
The necrotic damage increases to 1d6 at 6th level, 1d8 at 10th level, and 1d10 at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Symbiotic Entity
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to channel magic into your spores. When you hit an enemy with a melee attack, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to awaken those spores, rather than transforming into a beast form.
You gain 4 temporary hit points for each level you  have in this class. While this feature is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: When you deal your Halo of Spores damage, roll the damage die a second time and add it to the total.
Your melee attacks deal an extra 1d6 necrotic damage to any target they hit. This includes the attack triggering Symbiotic Entity.

entries: These benefits last for 10 minutes, until you lose all these temporary hit points, or until you use your Wild Shape again.

subclassFeature.name: Fungal Infestation
entries: At 6th level, your spores gain the ability to infest a corpse and animate it. If a beast or a humanoid that is Small or Medium dies within 10 feet of you, you can use your reaction to animate it, causing it to stand up immediately with 1 hit point. If the creature died as a result of your Halo of Spores damage, you do not need to use your reaction to trigger this effect. The creature uses the zombie stat block in the Monster Manual. It remains animate for 1 hour, after which time it collapses and dies.
In combat, the zombie's turn comes immediately after yours. It obeys your mental commands, and the only action it can take is the Attack action, making one melee attack.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.
Additionally, you have resistance to necrotic and poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Spreading Spores
entries: At 10th level, you gain the ability to seed an area with deadly spores. As a bonus action while your Symbiotic Entity feature is active, you can hurl spores up to 30 feet away. where they swirl in a 10-foot cube for 1 minute. The spores disappear early if you use this feature again, if you dismiss them as a bonus action, or if your Symbiotic Entity feature is no longer active.

Whenever a creature moves into the cube or starts its turn there, that creature takes your Halo of Spores damage, unless the creature succeeds on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. A creature can take this damage no more than once per turn.
While the cube of spores persists, you can't use your Halo of Spores reaction.

subclassFeature.name: Fungal Body
entries: At 14th level, the fungal spores in your body alter you: you can't be blinded, deafened, frightened, or poisoned, you gain immunity to necrotic damage and any critical hit against you counts as a normal hit instead, unless you're incapacitated.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Sun
entries: Druids of the Circle of the Sun, like their counterparts of the Circle of the Moon, are fierce guardians of nature. However, unlike the latter, they establish their villages in much more open and accessible areas so that they may bask in that which is the namesake of their circle. As a result, they are much less isolated and are considered to be among the most sociable of the druids.

In addition to the obvious partiality to fire and light, druids of the Circle of the Sun also have some affinity for plants, which likewise thrive under the sun's light. This affinity allows them to assume plant forms—an ability that truly sets them apart from their brethren.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your innate understanding of the radiant light, warmth and the sun itself grants you access to certain spells.
At 2nd level, you learn the light cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Sun Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

subclassFeature.name: Botanic Forms
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use Wild Shape to magically assume the form of a plant. This transformation must abide by the limitations shown in the Beast Shapes table.

subclassFeature.name: Glareproof
entries: Also at 2nd level, as one who glimpses the sun in veneration, your eyes become resistant to effects that could diminish their acuity in any way. If you have the Sunlight Sensitivity trait, you lose it. You also have advantage on saving throws against being blinded.
At 10th level, you become immune to being blinded.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Embrace
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you fail a saving throw while in bright light, you can reroll it and take the second result.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Herald of the Dawn
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can cast dawn without expending a spell slot or material components.
Once you cast dawn in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Synthesis
entries: Starting at 14th level, as plants are nourished by the sun's light and warmth, so does your body use the same energies to heal yourself. When you expend a spell slot to cast a spell that includes a fire or radiant damage roll, you regain hit points equal to 2 + the slot's level.
Additionally, basking in sunlight for 10 minutes provides you enough nourishment to sustain you for one day.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Storms
entries: Druids that are a part of the Circle of Storms emulate the strength and violence of a storm's natural wrath. They use their connection to strong weather to defend what they deem to be their sacred lands. Members of this circle are few, only meeting other circle members on special occasions. As such, it is not uncommon for these druids to join a local militia and help them protect the area from those who would harm it. Wherever these druids go, turmoil is sure to follow.

subclassFeature.name: Stormcaller
entries: At 2nd level, you can call storm clouds to your aid. You can summon a number of clouds equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) within 60 feet of you as an action. Each cloud creates a storm that affects a 10-foot-radius, 30-foot-high cylinder around the chosen point. When a creature enters or starts its turn in the storm's area of effect, it must make a saving throw or be affected by the storm. All saving throws are made against your Druid spell save DC. These affected areas are also heavily obscured.

These clouds can be dispersed by a strong wind (at least 30 miles per hour) and last for 1 minute or until you dispel them as a bonus action. Once you use this feature, you can not use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
The effect the clouds have on an area depends on the type of storm cloud you summon from the options below.

entries.name: Thunderstorm.
entries: Creatures exposed to your thunderstorms must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save a creature takes 2d8 lightning damage, or half as much on a success. If the affected creature remains in the thunderstorm for another round, it must succeed a Constitution saving throw or be deafened by the following thunder for 1 minute, in addition to the lightning damage taken. Deafened creatures can repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. You can use this storm to increase the damage dealt by the call lightning spell.

entries.name: Blizzard.
entries: Creatures exposed to your blizzards must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d6 cold damage, or half as much on a success, and its speed is reduced to 10 feet. The creature must repeat the saving throw if it remains in the blizzard's area.

entries.name: Tornado.
entries: Creatures exposed to your tornadoes must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone and pushed 10 feet in a random direction.

entries.name: Sandstorm.
entries: Creatures exposed to your sandstorms must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature is blinded for 1 minute. Blinded creatures can repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If the affected creature remains in the sandstorm for another round, it must succeed another Constitution saving throw or begin to suffocate.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Deflection
entries: Starting 6th level, you have learned to bend the elements of a thunderstorm. When you take lightning or thunder damage, you can use your reaction to halve the damage taken and redirect the additional damage to another creature within 30 feet of you.
The targeted creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Druid spell save DC. On a success, the creature takes no damage.

subclassFeature.name: Dangerous Conditions
entries: At 10th level, your summoned storms can become more deadly to those that face them. When you first summon your storms, you can combine two storm clouds to increase a storm's area to a 20-foot-radius, 50-foot-high cylinder around the chosen point. All creatures that enter these storms have disadvantage on all saving throws to avoid the cloud's effects and if the cloud deals damage, the number of damage die rolled is doubled.
Also, the area inside the storm is considered magical difficult terrain.

subclassFeature.name: Eye of the Storm
entries: By 14th level, you have mastered the manipulation of the air around you, allowing you to ride the wind and have it hinder your foes. You can cast the warding wind spell without expending a spell slot. While the spell is active, you gain a flying speed of 60 feet. You regain the use of this ability once you finish a short or long rest.
Also, when you fly away from a creature, it cannot get an attack of opportunity on you.
When you reach 18th level, warding wind no longer requires concentration when cast using this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Ancient Oak
entries: Monks of the Way of the Ancient Oak are known to be incredibly wise and compassionate people. They only anger when provoked, and prefer non-lethal solutions to problems when possible. Those who are experienced in the ways of the forest can call upon it for gifts - even at times, the gift of life.

entries.subclassFeature: Bamboo's Retort|Monk|PHB|Way of the Ancient Oak|Hergard|3
Ancient Oak's Acumen|Monk|PHB|Way of the Ancient Oak|Hergard|3

subclassFeature.name: Bamboo's Retort
entries: At 3rd level when you choose this tradition, whenever you take the Dodge action, you root your body to the ground until the start of your next turn, allowing you to absorb the force of blows and use it against a creature to great effect. If you are hit by a melee attack while you are in your stance, you can make an unarmed strike at the attacking creature (no action required) immediately at the start of your next turn. You cannot use any other monk features on said attack. You can react in this way to a number of creatures' attacks equal to half your proficiency bonus.
When you reach 6th level you can instead make two unarmed strikes at the start of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Ancient Oak's Acumen
entries: Also at 3rd level, your meditations in the forest have taught you to recognize the flow of ki through all creatures, regardless of origin. You can direct your attacks towards an enemy's ki points which are imperceivable to other beings and most other monks. You can use Wisdom instead of Dexterity for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed strikes which do psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Tranquil as a Forest
entries: Starting at 6th level, whenever a creature fails their save against your Stunning Strike feature, you can spend one ki to have that creature also be subject to the effects of the sleepspell.

subclassFeature.name: The Undergrowth's Curriculum
entries: At 11th level, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Teachings of the Tick.
entries: Your body weight drops to 1/4 its normal value, and if you end your turn on a vertical surface, you don't fall as long as that surface can support your weight.

entries.name: Grasshopper's Guidance.
entries: You can make a standing long jump or high jump up to 10 feet away.

entries.name: Ladybug's Lesson.
entries: As an action, you may spend 1 ki point to cast the spell plant growth without providing material components. When you choose the immediate benefit, you can also create light foliage easily capable of supporting 1/4 your normal weight up to 60 feet high. When you choose the long term benefit, you can magically rid the area of disease, infestation, or corruption.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of the Forest
entries: Beginning at 17th level, when you fall in battle your kindness to the forest is returned through their gift to you. As a reaction to being reduced to 0 hit points you may spend 5 ki points to let go your earthly tethers freeing your soul from your body. If your body still exists, its crumbles into dust.

A body forms from bark up to 30 feet away from where you fell, and your soul returns to it, reviving you at 20 hitpoints and with 3 points of exhaustion. You can choose to delay your return for up to one minute. When all of your exhaustion fades, your body returns to normal. You cannot use this feature for 14 days after you have been revived.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Cobalt Soul
entries: The Order of the Cobalt Soul; once formed by a group of rogue clerics of Titok who wanted to learn from untold knowledge, instead of hiding it forever, now a large system of librasteries across the continent guarded by the devoted members of the order. The monks of the Cobalt Soul are the embodiment of the phrase “know your enemy”. Through research, they prepare themselves against the ever-coming tides of evil.

Through careful training, they have learned to puncture and manipulate the spiritual flow of an opponent's body. Through understanding the secrets of their foe, they can adapt and surmount them. Then, once the fight is done, they return to record their findings for future generations of monks to study from.
"Be careful wanderer, for when the End of Time comes... the Cobalt Soul will know what to do."

entries.subclassFeature: Mystical Erudition|Monk|PHB|Way of the Cobalt Soul|Hergard|3
Extract Aspects|Monk|PHB|Way of the Cobalt Soul|Hergard|3

subclassFeature.name: Mystical Erudition
entries: Upon choosing this tradition at 3rd level, you have undergone extensive training with the Cobalt Soul, teaching you extensively in history and lore from the monastery's collected volumes. You learn one language of your choice, and you gain proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Arcana, History, Nature and Religion.

You gain an additional language and an additional skill proficiency from the above list at 11th and 17th level. If you already have proficiency in one of the listed skills at 11th or 17th level, you can instead choose to double your proficiency bonus for any ability check you make that uses the chosen proficiency.

subclassFeature.name: Extract Aspects
entries: Also at 3rd level, you can strike pressure points to extract crucial information about your foe. Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows feature, you can learn the following attributes about the target: Damage Vulnerabilities, Damage Resistances, Damage Immunities, and Condition Immunities.

subclassFeature.name: Extort Truth
entries: At 6th level, you can hit a series of hidden nerves on a creature with precision, temporarily causing them to be unable to mask their true thoughts and intent. If you manage to hit a single creature with two or more attacks in one round, you can spend 1 ki point to force them to make a Charisma saving throw. You can choose to have these attacks deal no damage. On a failed save, the creature is unable to speak a deliberate lie for 1 minute and all Charisma checks directed at the creature are made with advantage for the duration. You know if they succeeded or failed on their saving throw.

An affected creature is aware of the effect and can thus avoid answering questions to which it would normally respond with a lie. Such a creature can be evasive in its answers as long as the effect lasts.

subclassFeature.name: Preternatural Counter
entries: Beginning at 6th level, your quick mind and study of your foe allows you to use their failure to your advantage. If a creature misses you with an attack, you can immediately use your reaction to make an unarmed strike against that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Mind of Mercury
entries: Starting at 11th level, you've honed your awareness and reflexes through mental aptitude and pattern recognition. Once per turn, if you've already taken your reaction, you may spend 1 ki point to take an additional reaction. You can only use one reaction per trigger.
In addition, whenever you make an Intelligence (Investigation) check, you can spend 1 ki point to gain advantage on the roll.

subclassFeature.name: Debilitating Barrage
entries: Upon reaching 17th level, you've gained the knowledge to temporarily lower a creature's fortitude by striking a series of pressure points. Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows feature, you can spend 3 ki points to cause the creature to suffer a vulnerability to a damage type of your choice for 1 minute, or until they take damage of that type.

Then, once the fight is done, they return to record their findings for future generations of monks to study from.
